image.altText: Christopher Walker arrives at court wearing sunglasses

props.synopsis: Christopher Walker tells a court of his shame at the drug-fuelled incident, saying he has reformed and vows to help others struggling with addiction.

title.children: Driver of stolen car in fiery Sydney Harbour Bridge crash vows to help others 'transform'

image.altText: Actor Johnny Ruffo

props.synopsis: The star had been diagnosed with brain cancer for a second time, and was surrounded by his partner and family when he died, a message posted on Instagram says.

title.children: Johnny Ruffo, former Home and Away actor, dies from brain cancer aged 35

image.altText: A group of customers surround a retail worker inside of a shop

props.synopsis: First the hack, then the outage. Many customers want out of Optus, while others want compensation. Here's a look at your consumer rights.

title.children: Did you lose money because of the Optus outage? Here's how to try and get it back

image.altText: a black dual cab ute dumped at Wayne Richards Oval in Port Macquarie

props.synopsis: A 26-year-old Victorian man has faced court charged with several firearms offences after allegedly being under the influence of cocaine while involved in a series of shootings yesterday on the NSW Mid North Coast.

title.children: Man charged over shootings in Port Macquarie that led to 13-hour manhunt

image.altText: Scars from a mastectomy

props.synopsis: When Melanie Law's life depended on having her breasts removed, her appearance was the least of her concerns. But strangers and even health professionals saw it as an issue.

title.children: Melanie's life depended on having her breasts removed. When she chose to stay flat-chested, she was asked what her 'husband thought'

image.altText: A man carrying a baby with suitcases behind talking to another man amongst a crowd of people

props.synopsis: Israel has not yet officially confirmed a daily four-hour humanitarian pause, which the US says it agreed to, with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu saying safe passages for evacuation will be facilitated for "a few hours here or a few hours there". Follow live.

title.children: Biden praises 'humanitarian pauses' in Gaza fighting, but Netanyahu declines to confirm 'stoppages'

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Israeli PM Benjamin Netanyahu has said his country does not seek to conquer, occupy or govern Gaza after its war against Hamas but a "credible force" would be needed to enter the Palestinian enclave if necessary to prevent the emergence of militant threats. Netanyahu's comments this week suggesting that Israel would be responsible for Gaza security indefinitely drew pushback from the United States, Israel's main ally, with Washington saying it would oppose Israeli post-war occupation of Gaza. "We don't seek to conquer Gaza, we don't seek to occupy Gaza, and we don't seek to govern Gaza," Netanyau told Fox News. Netanyahu said a civilian government would need to take shape in Gaza but that Israel would make sure something like the October 7 attack does not happen again. "So, we have to have a credible force that, if necessary, will enter Gaza and kill the killers. Because that's what will prevent the reemergence of a Hamas-like entity," Netanyahu said. US officials say the Palestinian Authority (PA), which has limited self-rule in the Israeli-occupied West Bank, should return to govern Gaza after the war. Hamas seized control of Gaza from the PA forces of President Mahmoud Abbas in 2007. Top Palestinian officials, including Abbas, say a PA return to Gaza must be accompanied by a political solution that ends Israel's occupation of territory it captured in the 1967 Middle East war. Netanyahu said that after the war, "what we have to see is Gaza demilitarised, deradicalised and rebuilt". Palestinian Prime Minister Mohammad Shtayyeh told PBS this week the PA would not return to Gaza "on the back of an Israeli tank". Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israel does not seek to occupy Gaza, but 'credible force' needed, Netanyahu says

children.content: Israeli PM Benjamin Netanyahu has said his country does not seek to conquer, occupy or govern Gaza after its war against Hamas but a "credible force" would be needed to enter the Palestinian enclave if necessary to prevent the emergence of militant threats.

props.alt: Israeli prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu during a press conference in October.

children.content: Israeli Prime Minsiter Benjamin Netanyahu
(Reuters: Abir Sultan)

Netanyahu's comments this week suggesting that Israel would be responsible for Gaza security indefinitely drew pushback from the United States, Israel's main ally, with Washington saying it would oppose Israeli post-war occupation of Gaza.
"We don't seek to conquer Gaza, we don't seek to occupy Gaza, and we don't seek to govern Gaza," Netanyau told Fox News.
Netanyahu said a civilian government would need to take shape in Gaza but that Israel would make sure something like the October 7 attack does not happen again.
"So, we have to have a credible force that, if necessary, will enter Gaza and kill the killers. Because that's what will prevent the reemergence of a Hamas-like entity," Netanyahu said.

US officials say the Palestinian Authority (PA), which has limited self-rule in the Israeli-occupied West Bank, should return to govern Gaza after the war. Hamas seized control of Gaza from the PA forces of President Mahmoud Abbas in 2007.
Top Palestinian officials, including Abbas, say a PA return to Gaza must be accompanied by a political solution that ends Israel's occupation of territory it captured in the 1967 Middle East war.
Netanyahu said that after the war, "what we have to see is Gaza demilitarised, deradicalised and rebuilt".
Palestinian Prime Minister Mohammad Shtayyeh told PBS this week the PA would not return to Gaza "on the back of an Israeli tank".
Reuters

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A prominent humanitarian charity has accused Israel of attacking a hospital and blocking access to medical care during a military raid in the West Bank. Overnight Israel's military conducted a raid in the city of Jenin, reportedly killing 14 people. Doctors Without Borders said on the morning of the raid "leaflets were dropped on Jenin refugee camp, telling residents to evacuate, many of whom have no safe place to go". The group said it witnessed Israeli forces firing at the entrance of a hospital, shooting at an emergency unit and using military vehicles to block ambulances from entering hospitals. A paramedic was also shot while inside an ambulance, the charity said. "Hospitals are not targets and must remain safe spaces. Medical care must not be impeded," Doctors Without Borders said on X. "We call on the Israeli military to stop firing on hospitals and to stop their military vehicles from blocking ambulances and medical staff from reaching health care facilities." Israel's military has not released a response to these claims, but said on social media that it had conducted "counterterrorism activity" in the Jenin refugee camp and killed multiple terrorists.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Doctors Without Borders asks Israel to 'stop firing on hospitals' in the West Bank

children.content: A prominent humanitarian charity has accused Israel of attacking a hospital and blocking access to medical care during a military raid in the West Bank.
Overnight Israel's military conducted a raid in the city of Jenin, reportedly killing 14 people.
Doctors Without Borders said on the morning of the raid "leaflets were dropped on Jenin refugee camp, telling residents to evacuate, many of whom have no safe place to go".
The group said it witnessed Israeli forces firing at the entrance of a hospital, shooting at an emergency unit and using military vehicles to block ambulances from entering hospitals.
A paramedic was also shot while inside an ambulance, the charity said.
"Hospitals are not targets and must remain safe spaces. Medical care must not be impeded," Doctors Without Borders said on X.
"We call on the Israeli military to stop firing on hospitals and to stop their military vehicles from blocking ambulances and medical staff from reaching health care facilities."
Israel's military has not released a response to these claims, but said on social media that it had conducted "counterterrorism activity" in the Jenin refugee camp and killed multiple terrorists.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Fourteen Palestinians have been killed during an Israeli military raid in the West Bank, the local health ministry says, making it the deadliest single incursion in the West Bank since 2005, according to United Nations records. On Thursday (local time) the city of Jenin was rocked by dozens of explosions as Israeli armoured vehicles tore through the streets, fighting running battles with Palestinian gunmen using assault rifles and pipe bombs. Four more were killed elsewhere in the West Bank on Thursday, the health ministry said, putting the toll of Palestinians killed in the West Bank since October 7 at more than 180 people. Three Israelis were killed in violence in the West Bank over that period, according to officials. On Telegram the Israel Defense Forces confirmed it had conducted an operation in Jenin, claiming it had killed more than 10 terrorists and arrested more than 20 "wanted suspects". However advocacy organisation Defense for Children says two of those killed in Jenin on Thursday were children. Unlike Gaza, which is ruled by Hamas, the governing body in the West Bank is the Palestinian Authority. AFP/ABC
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israeli military raids city of Jenin in deadliest West Bank raid since 2005

children.content: Fourteen Palestinians have been killed during an Israeli military raid in the West Bank, the local health ministry says, making it the deadliest single incursion in the West Bank since 2005, according to United Nations records.

On Thursday (local time) the city of Jenin was rocked by dozens of explosions as Israeli armoured vehicles tore through the streets, fighting running battles with Palestinian gunmen using assault rifles and pipe bombs.
An Israeli army vehicle operates during an Israeli raid in Jenin.
(Reuters: Raneen Sawafta)
Palestinian children ride a bike by a damaged road after an Israeli raid in the Jenin refugee camp.
(Reuters: Raneen Sawafta)

Four more were killed elsewhere in the West Bank on Thursday, the health ministry said, putting the toll of Palestinians killed in the West Bank since October 7 at more than 180 people. Three Israelis were killed in violence in the West Bank over that period, according to officials.
On Telegram the Israel Defense Forces confirmed it had conducted an operation in Jenin, claiming it had killed more than 10 terrorists and arrested more than 20 "wanted suspects".
However advocacy
organisation Defense for Children says two of those killed in Jenin on Thursday were children.
Unlike Gaza, which is ruled by Hamas, the governing body in the West Bank is the Palestinian Authority.
AFP/ABC

image.altText: Villawood Immigration Detention Centre

props.synopsis: A man in immigration detention who had served a prison sentence for child sexual offences re-enters the community, with the government confirming dozens of others who were wrongly detained will soon follow.

title.children: Government confirms dozens held in indefinite detention will be released, as wrongly detained man re-enters community

image.altText: A man outside court

props.synopsis: Bobby Bourke has been sentenced to 18 months in prison, but he will not serve time behind bars, after being found guilty of misconduct in public office for helping to blackmail fellow councillor Jacqui Rudge in 2020.

title.children: Former Bathurst mayor Robert 'Bobby' Bourke evades jail time for blackmail

image.altText: Woman with black glasses and a blue shirt taking a call with headphones.

props.synopsis: The domestic violence helpline takes 18,000 calls a year from women who may have few other options to find help, as statistics reveal 37 per cent of women in NSW over the age of 15 are experiencing physical and/or sexual violence.

title.children: Josephine's been taking domestic violence crisis calls for 20 years. This is what she's learned

image.altText: People sitting on the ground.

props.synopsis: Australian Taylor Swift fans have been camping out overnight in the hope of securing tickets to the US singer's Eras tour concerts.

title.children: Taylor Swift concert ticket frenzy sees fans sleeping in queues

image.altText: A heat map of the Earth on July 11, 2023.

props.synopsis: Between November 2022 and October this year, the average global temperature was more than 1.3 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels, and more record highs are on the way.

title.children: Hottest 12 months in probably 125,000 years, with El Niño only just getting started

image.altText: A large image of Netayahu's face, partially obscured by flags and protesters

props.synopsis: Benjamin Netanyahu is being blamed by many Israelis for the failures that contributed to the horrors of October 7. He is now trying to hang on to power.

title.children: 50 years on from the Yom Kippur War, will history repeat itself for Israel's PM?

image.altText: Two women look at a share price board outside the ASX in Sydney.

props.synopsis: The ASX is trading lower after the RBA gave its latest economic update, outlining that inflation is unlikely to return to target until December 2025, while the US Federal Reserve warns interest rates may not be high enough. Follow live.

title.children: ASX lower as RBA adjusts inflation expectations, US Federal Reserve 'not confident' rates high enough

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: If you missed it yesterday, NAB delivered a $7.4 billion full-year profit in its results, and increased the full year dividend to $1.67. The country's second biggest bank said the 12 rate rises in just over a year helped deliver the results, describing it as a once in a lifetime opportunity. NAB's boss Ross McEwan acknowledged that mortgage stress is rising, but despite the rate hikes borrowers are handing it — for now. He sat down with Alicia Barry on The Business last night to discuss the results, and why he expects house prices will keep rising this year and into 2024. You can watch their full chat below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 📺 ICYMI: Why house prices will keep rising, according to the boss of NAB

NAB's boss Ross McEwan

He sat down with

last night to discuss the results, and why he expects house prices will keep rising this year and into 2024.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A crisis management and reputation specialist says Optus failed to communicate successfully with Australians during this week's nationwide outage. Optus says a rare technical issue was behind the outage, and has announced it's acknowledging the "patience and loyalty" of customers by giving them free data — but many consumers argue their losses are worth much more. The federal government has also announced an inquiry into the outage which impacted emergency services, transport networks and shut down business payments. Crisis PR expert Sally Branson says Optus' response may have done more damage to its reputation than the outage itself, and is surprised the telco doesn't grasp the scale of the problem — especially after last year's cyber attack. "For all the great work that Optus does around sponsorship of the Matildas ... is so expensive to do, but it fails when the core business of providing communications falls down," she said. "It's 2023, we don't expect CEOs to hide. "There's cafes all over the country who are waiting on IOU's for their flat whites, and a bit of a data package thrown my way, I'd be pretty upset. "If Optus' key messaging is they support Australian business, that needs to be more than data."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Optus' response may damage reputation more than the outage, crisis PR expert says

children.content: A crisis management and reputation specialist says

Optus says a rare technical issue was behind the outage, and has announced it's acknowledging the "patience and loyalty" of customers by giving them free data — but many consumers argue their losses are worth much more.
The federal government has also announced an inquiry into the outage which impacted emergency services, transport networks and shut down business payments.
Crisis PR expert Sally Branson

"For all the great work that Optus does around sponsorship of the Matildas ... is so expensive to do, but it fails when the core business of providing communications falls down," she said.

"There's cafes all over the country who are waiting on IOU's for their flat whites, and a bit of a data package thrown my way, I'd be pretty upset.
"If Optus' key messaging is they support Australian business, that needs to be more than data."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The ASX is firmly in the red at lunch, down 0.5% to 6,980 points at the time of posting. (If it's live figures you're after, jump to the top of the blog.) Any gains it's made so far this week are now nowhere to be found, meaning the ASX is on track to close at the lowest level all week. The falls come after the RBA increased its inflation forecasts in its latest statement of monetary policy. It now expects inflation to fall to 4.5% by December, but wouldn't reach the top of its 2-3% target band until December 2025. Meanwhile, all but one of the sectors are in the red — basic materials is up 0.2%. Utilities has fallen the most (-1.4%), followed by financials (-1%), industrials (-0.9%), energy (-0.8%) and academic and educational services (-0.8%). Both technology and consumer non-cyclicals have dipped by 0.7%, followed by real estate (-0.6%), consumer cyclicals (-0.5%) and healthcare (-0.4%). As for the best performers: Neuren Pharmaceuticals +4.8% Breville +2.5% Light & Wonder +1.4% Emerald Resources +1.4% Fortescue Metals +1.3% And the worst performers: Sayona Mining -6.9% Chalice Mining -6.4% Core Lithium -5.8% Healius -4.7% Alumina -4%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX loses all its gains for the week as the RBA raises its inflation forecasts

image.altText: One man speaks in front of media microphones, with two men standing behind him on either side

props.synopsis: The South Australian government will give land to the federal government to build nuclear submarines in exchange for three sites, two of which it plans to use for new housing.

title.children: South Australia reaches land-swap deal with federal government

image.altText: Smoke rises after an Israeli air strike on Gaza.

props.synopsis: As Israeli forces fight Hamas militants among ruined buildings in the north of the Gaza Strip, inching their way closer to two big hospitals, the UN human rights chief accuses both Israel and Hamas of war crimes.

title.children: Heavy fighting in northern Gaza as White House says Israel has agreed to four-hour 'humanitarian pauses'

image.altText: Business people walk past a shiny black sign that reads "Reserve Bank of Australia".

props.synopsis: The Reserve Bank reveals the reasoning behind its latest interest rate rise and whether it is likely to have to lift them again.

title.children: Record population growth a double-edged sword for inflation, according to RBA analysis

image.altText: An older man wearing a red and blue AFL scarf, in a suit, smiles widely in happiness.

props.synopsis: Football legend Ron Barassi has been remembered as the father of modern AFL in a state memorial service at the MCG, with tributes labelling him an "outstanding human" and "competitive mongrel".

title.children: AFL community farewells Ron Barassi, 'the greatest' to have ever played the game

image.altText: Johnathan Davis speaks to the media.

props.synopsis: ACT member of the legislative assembly Johnathan Davis is stood down over allegations of misconduct, which a Greens spokesperson has confirmed are "of a sexual nature".

title.children: ACT Greens politician Johnathan Davis stood down over allegations of misconduct of 'sexual nature'

image.altText: An long-beaked echidna walks amid vegetation in the Cyclops Mountains, Papua in a black and white screengrab.

props.synopsis: Scientists rediscover a long-lost species of mammal described as having the spines of a hedgehog, the snout of an anteater and the feet of a mole, in Papua's Cyclops Mountains more than 60 years after it was last recorded.

title.children: Long-beaked echidna rediscovered in remote Papua mountains after 60 years

image.altText: generic photo of psychologist's hand holding a pen with a patient

props.synopsis: A psychology student says there is a logjam of candidates trying to finish their study while forced to wait years for placements that are crucial to gaining their qualifications.

title.children: Psychology study bottleneck restricts flow of graduates into in-demand profession

image.altText: A man inside a ship, wearing a big coat, and looking out to see

props.synopsis: Partisans in Crimea claim they provided critical intelligence to Ukraine's armed forces about Russia's Black Sea navy headquarters before it was destroyed by a missile attack in September.

title.children: Russia took this part of Ukraine — it's now facing a new enemy inside the occupied territory

image.altText: flowers and pictures with candles

props.synopsis: Friends and family of the five people killed in a horror pub crash in Daylesford call for ongoing support as they give tearful tributes to their loved ones.

title.children: Outpouring of grief in Melbourne's west for Daylesford victims

image.altText: A man sitting in a chair in hospital smiling getting blood pressure taken

props.synopsis: There are no PET scanners available in Eustie King's central Queensland home town. He says regular long-distance travel is taking a toll as he fights two types of cancer.

title.children: Regional cancer patients are driving hundreds of kilometres for a diagnosis. Eustie wants to change that

image.altText: Two actors standing side by side in front of the Sydney Harbour Bridge with one wearing a cap with NCIS written on it

props.synopsis: The head of scripted for the new NCIS: Sydney has used the knowledge of her hometown to develop a unique character for the new wing of the television franchise.

title.children: Homegrown crew highlights the best of the Harbour City in NCIS: Sydney

image.altText: Robert De Niro appears on the red carpet in Cannes.

props.synopsis: A jury finds that a company the Oscar-winning actor formed to look after his personal needs was liable for gender discrimination and retaliation.

title.children: Robert De Niro's former assistant awarded $1.88 million in gender discrimination lawsuit

image.altText: A transplanted eye is examined by a doctor wearing a blue glove.

props.synopsis: Surgeons in New York perform the first whole-eye transplant in a human, an accomplishment being hailed as a breakthrough even though the patient has not regained sight in the eye.

title.children: 'Huge step forward': Surgeons in New York announce world's first whole-eye transplant

image.altText: a flooded road bridge

props.synopsis: Firefighters and property owners give thanks for a large downpour that has helped quell a ferocious fire that tore through more than 200,000 hectares and sparked evacuations.

title.children: 'Miracle' rain brings relief to fire-ravaged outback Queensland

image.altText: Oliva O'Flynn sits with her chin resting on her fist as she looks into the camera

props.synopsis: For those of us who don't have a belief system, who do we turn to when confronted with unimaginable loss? If the internet has replaced community, do I turn to TikTok?

title.children: I'm not alone in the face of impending loss. It's comforting to know I won't be alone when it's time to grieve

image.altText: A man with a backpack on leans forward to get into the back of a car with two police officers behind him

props.synopsis: Police charge the former pro boxer and Australian Olympic boxing team captain with dealing with property reasonably suspected of being proceeds of crime, after an arrest at Hobart Airport.

title.children: Boxer Luke Jackson arrested with $150k cash in luggage, police allege

image.altText: A man looking sad and staring at the camera.

props.synopsis: Kamal El-Gadba was in Gaza for the first time in 12 years, meeting the newest additions to his family and catching up on old times. Then war broke out.

title.children: Australian man reunited with daughters after weeks stuck in Gaza

image.altText: A close-up shot of a monkey looking right at the camera baring its teeth against a green backdrop

props.synopsis: Researchers in China have reported the live birth of a monkey chimera using a stem cell technique previously only successful with rats and mice. So what does this mean?

title.children: Scientists create monkey 'chimera' using stem cells for the first time
